“Doctor Arendelle.”

“Hmm?” she sucks in her breath.
“Is it morning already?

!”

“Doctor Arendelle!” The voice speaks again, this time followed by a gentle shake of her shoulders.
“Anna?” Elsa giggles, eyes half-closed.

“Is that you?” Then she slumps over again, “Why are you calling me that name?”

“This isn’t going to work, is it?” The voice—the voice of a man— grumbles.
She hears a light sigh and the next thing she knew, her face stopped flirting with the table and she was in the arms of someone whose voice her ears recognize but her mind can’t seem to comprehend.
At least he smells nice.

Chapter 4: A night spent together

This is crazy.
Jack thinks.
You’re fucking crazy.
He curses himself.

If someone told Jack this morning that he would soon have Doctor fucking Arendelle in his bed the same random Tuesday night, he would tell you you were crazy—or high, or both—and slap you in the face.
Hard.
Cause really, he would’ve thought you were crazy and that maybe—just maybe—you needed more professional help than he did.
That fact, in itself, was crazy.

But here he is, Jackson Overland Frost, sitting in nothing but his boxers and sweats, chopsticks in one hand and sushi plate in another—afraid that the next bite would wake her up—and Doctor Arendelle—his fucking psychiatrist—laying in his bed, in her night blue, skin-tight, dress, in his studio apartment, in the far corner, restlessly moving and shoving and kicking around in his sheets.
She was ingraining her scent all over them.
He fights the urge to punch himself and scolds his mind for ever thinking—ever letting himself think—that.

“Mmm…”

He freezes and feels his palms sweat and clings onto his plate for dear life because—

Because if the damn fucking plate drops… his life may as well have been over.
Jack then sees his psychiatrist try to lift herself up from his bed and he swears he almost pissed his pants.

“Where am I?” 

He hears her faintly mumble to herself, voice a little shaky and disgruntled, and everything in between.
He tries his best to stay still and unnoticed but she still senses him there.

“Is there someone else here?”

It must’ve been her sixth psychiatrist-related sense; mindreading or something, he assumes.
“I know you’re there.” He hears her shuffling around a bit more.
Yup, mindreading for sure.
He lets out the breath he was holding and steps into the moonlight shining through his window and surrenders himself to her.
“‘Sup,” was all he could say.
In the light, he catches sight of her eyes squinting—probably to fix her vision on him and make out the mystery man.
“Jack?” she questions.
She’s fucking psychic, he concludes.
“The one and only,” he responds as he steps closer to her—to his bed.
He knew she’s intoxicated and heavily under the influence right now, but he still treks with caution.
“It’s so unbelievably…” she starts and wiggles around in his sheets, further cementing her scent onto his territory.

“Hot…” 

He can see her fidgeting around, struggling to do something.
He couldn’t quite yet tell what though.
“Jack,” she starts.

“Hm?” His eyes wander all over her body, and he hates his conscience for stopping his gaze at her breasts; they were more voluptuous than he initially thought—but to be fair, the dress left little for imagination while her lab coat hid them well.
His throat runs cold as he notices a bead of sweat on her right mound.
He’s more than fucked.

“Stop standing there.”

“Pardon?”

“Come and help get this dress off of me.” She groans and sways back and forth as he notices her hands wander…

“What the—” He gasps and stops himself from saying anything more and just stands there, a few feet away from his bed.
“You know…” She starts her drunk rambles.
“For someone as fucking hot as you—” and tugs at the top of her tube dress.
A sweat trickles down his forehead and he gulps as he claws his wet fists deep into the pockets of his gray sweatpants.
He was starting to get hot too.
It must’ve been the temperature that was bothering the both of them.
He should probably stop her.

“Doctor—”

She sighs the sigh to end all sighs—a little exaggerated, extremely dramatic, and royally sassy, “Again with that title.

Didn’t I tell you before, Jack?”

“Uhm…” He wiggles his fingers in his pockets in hopes of wiping some of the sweat away.

“Tell me what, exactly?”

“To call me Elsa.”

“You did?”

She stops and stares at him for a little bit—a little too long for his comfort but a little too short to deem her a creep—and proceeds to shrug.
“Well—maybe in my dreams I did.” She mumbles the last part.
But it was a little past midnight, and with the streets—though they were nineteen floors below them—quiet, devoid of the typical road-raging driver and angry honks, it was hard not to hear her.
He gulps for about the tenth time that night.
“Oh—” And even though she’s drunk and probably won’t remember anything a few hours from now, he’s still at a loss for the right words to say to the woman before him.

“I—I see.”

He keeps his gaze on her as she (still) tries to strip herself.
He winces.

“I don’t think you should do that.”

“Why not?” 

And with that damned look on her face—he finds it a little bit hard to not lose himself.
“You’re already half naked,” she comments and then giggles—like a fucking schoolgirl.

“So really, what’s wrong, Jack?”’

He finds himself gulping for the hundredth (but really it must’ve been the eleventh) time that night—which he should probably stop doing because he was already dehydrated.
Elsa has a look on her face now, probably annoyed at his response (or lack of).
“Stop standing there,” she beckons for him.

“How many more times do I have to ask?” 

Drawn in by her voice in the middle of the night, with his mind too tired to fight back, and his heart, beating wildly and threatening to roll right out of his chest, Jack walks over.

Chapter 5: a morning after,

The first thing Elsa does when she wakes up is groan to herself.
Her head spins at a pace where her conscience can’t keep up.
She rubs her hand on the sheet, once, twice—and her eyebrows furrow into each other.
The blanket is a lot softer and thinner than what she’s used to every morning.
When her brain finally catches up, she realizes that this isn’t even her blanket.
Nor is this her bed—or her damn room.
And then all at once, a feeling of pure, utter dread hits.
All of a sudden, she’s sober again.
Now her mind does another frantic dance with itself, trying to figure out that—if this isn’t her room (nor is it Anna’s) or Hans for that matter—then who did the room belong to?
She looks down at herself, her arm still tugging the thin blanket across her chest, and winces prematurely when she carefully opens it to reveal the rest of her body.
To her relief, she was still in the same dress she left her house wearing last night—for the most part.

She takes a deep breath and then her wide blue eyes look; she doesn’t know what she’s looking for—hell she isn’t even sure if she wants to know—but she does so anyway because that’s, quite honestly, the most logical thing she could do given her situation.
But, for good measure, she pinches herself just to make sure she’s awake and that this is her reality.
(It is.)
When her eyes make it sixty percent across the room, she hears the person rather than sees them.
“Finally awake?” A cool, crisp, almost teasing, voice startles her investigation.
Her heart stops, and her face twists further into itself when she realizes—recognizes—who the voice belongs to.
“Jackson?” She throws out randomly, not looking at him and crossing her fingers, hoping, that this was just someone who just happened to sound like her fucking patient.
“At your service, Doctor Arendelle.” He gets up from the couch he was sitting at in his studio apartment and puts his coffee down, stretching.
Motherfucking stretching.
She curses out, earning an ingenuine chuckle from the dreadful man.
“Did—” she points between them, frantic and awkward and hoping.

“Did something happen between us?”

This earns a laugh from him.

At the end of it, she hears a funny “No.”

She must’ve had some doubts on her face, because he says some more, “I can one hundred percent assure you, Doctor, that our relationship as patient and doctor did not—and probably will not—cross that line.”

“Then…” she sucks in a breath and asks another terribly unprofessional question.

“Then how… how did I get here?”

“The lady at the sushi restaurant more or less made you my problem,” he says, trying his best to make it seem like it is nothing to him—but from her experience as his psychiatrist, she knows.

“Apparently the man you were with left… and never came back.” 

When she doesn’t say anything and takes the time to process, he adds, “You can ask her—if you doubt me—I wouldn’t take offense to that.” 

When he feels the need to explain and give himself an alibi, she only shakes her head, guiltily.
She fucked up.
“Oh my god, Jackson…” her eyes widen more when they finally, actually look at him.
“I’m so, so sorry about this.
This shouldn’t even have happened.

How terribly unpro—“

“Like I said, Doctor Arendelle.” 

She winces at his title for her and resists the very strong urge to slap herself.
Because this was so not happening.
“It’s not a problem.

I don’t mind helping you out, and you shouldn’t either, just take this gesture as something any acquaintance would do,” he says too cheerily and nonchalantly and for once in her life, she needs to stop psychoanalyzing him.
“Or else it’ll make it weird—for the both of us.”
Tap, tap tap.

“When I get home I want you~”
Tap, tap tap.
Jack thrums his fingers against his aged steering wheel, passionately singing along to the song, like he’s the only one there.

Physically, he is the only one there—here—in his 2007 light blue, Toyota Camry, but in hindsight, he’s not the only one—
“Can you shut the fuck up?” Aster’s voice, annoyed and irritated and bothered (as always), sounds from the other side of his phone.
“Just turn me down, dumbass,” Jack says into the device.
And even though his best friend wouldn’t see it, he rolls his eyes for the sake of doing so.
He switches his lane on the freeway in the middle of all this.
“Or, I can just hang up,” the Australian man replies, as a matter of fact.
It takes all of Jack’s self-control to withhold his annoyance at his friend—friendly annoyance, yes, never serious, yes—but still so damn annoying.
“Bunny!” he exclaims into the phone, appalled at the threat, “Not on my big day!

I need you for moral support.”
“Or someone for you to keep yapping to.”
“To keep me sane!”
“Is it that big a deal, mate?”
Jack gasps, loud and clear even above the upbeat music and bass and drums blasting through his car’s old, tired speakers.
“Yes, Bunny, it’s only the day I hear back from the job of the century, Bunny!

A TA, imagine that!”
A sigh comes from his phone, “Did they at least tell you what time you’ll hear back?”
Jack shrugs, but it’s not like Bunny can see him.

“Nope.” He pops his p. “Only that it’ll be today.”
Another sigh, and then silence.

“Like me next to you, and you next to me~and you next to—”
“I said to shut up.”
“Turn me down?”
“Then I wouldn’t be able to hear you when you say something important.”
Jack wants to laugh, “When have I ever said something important?”
A silence, and then, “You’re right.”
“I always am,” a satisfied smile forms on his lips, even though he’s the only one to know.

“Still, I mean it, Jackson, if you want me to stay on the phone with you, stop singing—at least not so damn loud—I’m trying to get this problem set done.”
Jack turns on his right blinker, successfully switches lane, and has just gotten off the freeway exit when he replies again, “Yes dad.”
He’s at a stoplight now, right blinker still on, waiting to turn.

“I’m telling Toothi—“
HONKKKK.
“Oh—fuck.

Shit!”

And then Aster hears a loud and deafening beeeep.
His head hurts.
Everything kind of sort of hurts.
There’s a slight ringing in his ears and he isn’t sure where it’s coming from.
“Owowowow—“ he winces in pain as he fights the inflated airbag and his seatbelt and the door, all at once.

“Oh my god!”
Through all the ringing he’s hearing—or imagining—an angelic voice makes it through to him.
“I’m so sorry.” It says.
“Are you okay?” It says.
“Does it hurt anymore?” A pair of thin arms helps itself to him, wrapping themselves around him.
“Shit, I should call the cops…” the voice says to no one in particular, him maybe but he’s in a state where he isn’t even sure if it’s real.
Once he’s out, he stumbles around a bit, but the same pair of arms help him find his balance, sitting him on the road against his car.
His mind is slow.
But it soon catches up.
And he looks up.
A pair of eyes so blue and bright looks at him—they dart all over him.
“Yeah,” he manages to say when words find their way back to him, when his brain finally processes everything.

“Yeah, I’m fine.” 
He looks around him and takes the rest of the scene in.
The front of his car is fine.
The back, however, isn’t as much—in fact—a fucking Bentley, is kissing its ass.
His trunk is open, probably from the impact, and he sees what looks to be a dent: noticeable, but it won’t cost a leg and arm to repair.
He cringes when he notices the condition of its ass kisser though.
The Bentley has a lot—too much—scratches and dents all over it.
He squints and he even sees a faint cloud of steam coming from under its hood.

His eyes then trail to the girl hovering over him, and words are hard again, but by some miraculous nature, he manages, “The Bentley… maybe not as fine.”
Then, despite the tragedy and unfortunate circumstance of the situation, “Battle scars are sexy, but not on a Bentley,” he quips.
(But it’s more done out of a habit—Jack defaults to humor when he doesn’t know what the fuck else to do).
And, with the combination of the accident, a pretty girl, the state of his car, and the state of her car (the terrible, terrible tragedy), he finds himself a sitting duck.
Helpless and staring.
“That’s good,” she says.

“Stay here while I call the cops—and my parents—“
He notices the tapping of her baby blue kitten heels.
“Oh god, what would they think—say?

!”
Despite being on the ground, and still a little dazed, he finds it in himself to console her worried self, “Relax, I’m sure they’ll understand.” And then he takes a look at the Bentley, “To some extent.”
The girl turns to look at him, her phone in one hand, mid-dial.

“Do you know what happened?”
He shakes his head, but in the middle of doing so, he’s racking his brain for the memories, “I was making a right turn…” he thinks out loud.

“Turning on a green…”
His mouth morphs into a silent ‘o’ as he looks at her again, eyes slightly wide.
“Yeah,” she nods, lips thinning into a frown.

Her eyebrows are knitted together as she confesses, “It was my fault… I was—“
He waits patiently for her truth.
“Going a little too fast.” Then for no other reason (because she isn’t obligated to tell him the details), “I was going sixty.

On a twenty-five.”
He doesn’t know what to say.
I see?
Nope, the conversation would die—and it’ll get awkward, he doesn’t want it to get awkward, because they’re stuck with each other until the cops come—and god knows how long that’ll be.

Between Towne and its freeway exit, yes.

Beep.

“Late to class.”
He blinks and tries—let it be known he really really tried—his best to hold in his laugh, but he fails.

Elsa Arendelle.”

“So…” he starts, waiting for her attention.
He continues when he gets it, “Want a ride?

I was heading back to school too.”
She blinks, confused for a split second, but then realization finds her face.

“You go to Northton?”
He nods, “Yup.”
“Sure,” she says and follows him as he opens the passenger seat for her.
For some reason, he can tell she’s not entirely present.
If it was bothering him, then Jack doesn’t dare voice it out loud as he wraps around to the driver’s seat, gets in, and closes the door.
They sit in silence for the entirety of the five-minute ride (because they were that close to making it back with no mishaps).

Jack’s right blinkers are on as he begins his turn into the campus parking lot when—
“Finally, I remember!” Elsa physically jumps in her seat from his peripheral.

And then she turns to him,

“You’re Jackson Overland, right?”
Tick.
Tick.
Tick.
“So what are your bad habits?” The white-haired man leans further back into his bean bag as he tries his best to undo the much-too-tight knot at the base of his tie.
He tells himself he should remind Tooth to not tie it so damn fucking tight next time.
But he knows their conversation is going to end with her annoying boyfriend scolding him in his annoying Aussie accent.

‘Be grateful you jerk.’

Or, ‘Have your nonexistent girlfriend do it for you next time.’ 

“Uhm… Mister?” The strawberry blonde woman calls out to him, from across his makeshift office.

But really they’re just in the living room, with a mahogany coffee table, low enough for him to use it as a leg prop, separating the woman—who’s on the relatively old, relatively soft, couch—and him—on the bean bag he dragged out of his room to do this meeting comfortably on.
It’s at her call that he remembers he’s supposed to be interviewing her for the (most covetable) position as his roommate.
He’s been a sitting duck, struggling to pay rent ever since his former roommate, Hiccup, had left him to live with his girlfriend.
Like is he fucking kidding?
He’d rather live with his girlfriend than his best friend?

(And his friends tell him he never will, but if asked he would say he has no idea what they’re talking about because he—as much as his friends say otherwise—has rizz.)

What was I asking again?”

“Your sister?” Jack mirrors her motion and gets up as well.
“What about her?

And why is she brought up again?” 

Real mature, Jack.
Real fucking mature.
“Oh yeah, I’m—I’m actually interviewing for her because she couldn’t make it today…” Anna sends him a small smile before leaning down again to grab her purse on the low table between them.
“But you know… she’s very…” she looks around for a bit, refusing to make eye contact with Jack.

“Specific about the people she wants to live with.”

Jack blinks in confusion.

“So I’m sorr—“

“Wait,” Realization dawns on him as he finally catches hold of the pity on his interviewee’s face.

“Are you… rejecting me?”

“…”

“As the person I’m interviewing?”

Anna gives him a scared look and she mouths a weak, silent, ‘I’m so sorry’.
For whatever reason, she decides to stand there though.
Maybe because she regrets getting up on him or maybe because she’s a really nice girl and can’t fathom the idea of leaving him hanging.
“So… you’re interviewing in place of your sister… Elsa, right?” Jack tries again with her.

“I’m sorry that was—I was just lost in my thoughts for a bit, I’m sorry.”

(And despite apologizing, he lowkey thinks she’s a little bit crazy for deciding that living with him was a bad idea because he zoned out a smidge.)
Just a smidge.
“Oh no worries, I wouldn’t care,” she tells him as if she has access to his thoughts.

“It’s just that—my sister… Elsa…”

“Elsa…” Jack repeats after her, urging her to go on about the reason—the person—why she almost leaves him hanging for.
(He’s totally aware that this isn’t a date or whatever though, or even close to one at all, but still).

But still…

“She’s… mmm,” Anna’s thinking really hard.

“How do I say this…” 

“She can’t be that bad, right?” And really, does he want to know?
What if it’s something really bad or really gross or really… wait what if she’s a fucking murderer or something.
Maybe he should just let the woman leave.
“No!” Anna shouts to save her sister’s reputation.

“It’s not what you’re thinking it is.”

He’s convinced she’s a mind reader.
“Then what is it?” He asks casually, hoping she doesn’t catch a glimpse of his sweaty palms or hear the waver in his voice.
“She’s just very… proper.
Prim.

Sophisticated, elegant, technical… clean…”

Jack can’t decide if she’s insulting him or if she means it.
He finds the latter hard to believe though, because how can anyone really be all that?
If he didn’t know better and if they weren’t living in the 21st century, he’d have thought she was describing a queen.
But he can’t give this Elsa person up either, because— quite frankly—he doesn’t want to be living off of instant ramen and pizza anymore.
Quite frankly, he kind of wants to enjoy his weekends not alone and at home just because he has to be mindful of his spending.

“Tell you what… how about you tell this Elsa sister of yours, to text me…” he drawls on as he scribbles his number on the paperwork (it was just one page that he typed up the night before to sell the lie that he’s a professional) and slides it over to her.

“And we can set up a meeting time when she’s free.” 

Anna sighs a sigh of relief and Jack guesses it’s because she doesn’t have to walk out on their interview.
“Yeah, of course,” then a wide smile forms on her lips.
“And who knows, maybe the next time we see each other, I’ll be your housemate’s sister instead.” She says casually to clear the tension—or whatever this awkwardness was—between them.
As they finish their goodbyes, Jack hopes the next time he sees the giddy woman, it’ll be under different, less awkward, circumstances.
He realizes he doesn’t even know her name.

He was almost there.

Almost simultaneously, the wind, which kept him from gravity’s grasp, hesitated— more than it already has since his trek from the North Pole.
Normally, Jack would’ve been ecstatic to visit his queen’s abode.
But tonight was different.
After tonight, he would no longer have a reason to.
There would be no more Elsa to tease and spoil.
No more crazy Anna shipping and fangirling over the Winter Spirit and his Snow Queen.
No more stealing glances at the eternally graceful and ever-beautiful girl as she sits at her desk, scratching her pen over some sort of letter or document that would steal her attention from him.
No more late-night talks where both ice deities would only suffer its aftermath when the rest of the world woke from slumber in all directions.
No more incentive to visit after tonight— unless he wants his heart to shatter into pieces, more than it already has.
If that’s even possible.
He shook the haunting thoughts out of his head as quickly as it came.
You shouldn’t be out and about wasting your time.
He scolded himself.
You may have the rest of forever to waste but she doesn’t.
And in what felt like an eternity, even for the fun and mischievous, winter spirit, Jack Frost, he was at the edge of Arendelle castle.
At last.

❄❄❄❄❄❄❄
Being in the presence of the towering doors was foreign to him.
If given the option between the intimidating doors and Elsa’s window, he would always opt with the latter.
But tonight was different.
He had a feeling that Anna was at her sister’s bedside.
Intruding on their last moments together would be the last thing he wanted— apart from Elsa leaving him forever of course.
As considerate as he was, his pondering was cut short when he came across the first person he’d see all night.
The guard, a few feet away from him, silently acknowledged his presence and led him through one of the doors, into the halls.
Apart from a few servants who passed by the unusual duo, the castle was empty and quiet.
Acknowledgments and greetings were mutually made through eye contact and subtle nods.
No one saw fit to speak or make any more sound than was necessary, afraid that the noise would disturb the shared solemnity and stab the blanket of grief.
As the distance between Elsa’s room and him shortened, the lower the temperature got.
Although he tried to be discreet, the guard subtly shivered at the sudden change.
But Jack was indifferent to it.
Like his counterpart, the cold never bothered him anyway.
Yards turned into feet and feet turned into inches.
Finally, like all journeys, his dreaded one came to a halt.
Jack was finally here.
He was mere centimeters away from her door.
Afraid to be in the presence of the spirit’s sorrow, the guard motioned his farewells and scurried back to his original post.
As for Jack, like the wind that carried him thousands of miles here, he hesitated.
Who was he to knock and cut short the remaining time the royal sisters had together?
Plus, his dying lover was on the other side of this door.
And the thought killed him.

❄❄❄❄❄❄
Luckily, he didn’t have to knock.
The door was opened and a waft of even colder air wrapped around his pale face.

Anna was crying.
Crying was an understatement.
Jack looked at Anna’s tear-stained face.
He didn’t know that the always cheerful, goofy, fun, and loving Anna was capable of making such a face.
Worse, he didn’t know if Anna would ever return to her once bubbly self.
She had already spent a decade or so without her sister.
And spending the rest of her life without Elsa was way too cruel.
Kristoff, who looked just as bad as his wife followed behind her, his giant hand on her shaking shoulders.
The husband-wife pair walked past Jack, both parties silently addressing each other.
Anna quickly walked away from the hall, not wanting to be near Elsa when she takes her final breath.
And Jack couldn’t blame her.
How can anyone go on living if they witnessed the passing of someone so dear to them.
Shortly behind her, Kristoff gave Jack a most pitiful look before following Anna down the hall, hoping to not only console her but himself as well.
Now all there was before Jack was himself.
And an open door.

She wasn’t scared of death, never was, never is.

Her beloved kingdom would recover from their queen’s passing under Anna and Kristoff’s rule.

Sven?
Olaf?
Jack?
Jack.

No, not yet.
Her melancholy thoughts fizzled out as she heard a light sigh at her door.
A sigh so soft that any other type of noise would drown it out.
Except, there was no other noise in the vicinity, besides two beating hearts and their ever so subtle breathing.
Her head snapped to the source so fast, it seemed like she practiced doing so all her life— waiting for the right moment to do so.

“Jack?”

Elsa was under the ‘average person’ category because, if it wasn’t for the droplet, she would’ve for sure missed it.
But she was in no way a ‘normal person’.
Major franchises be damned if it means she finally has a haven from the rain and a place to enjoy her book in, which was waiting for her safely in the covert of her bag.
Ring.

Jack grinned as he took the seat across from her, internally celebrating his triumph over her stubbornness.
Afraid to waste the time he was generously given, he bombarded the poor girl with questions right away.

“May I have your name?”
She looked up from her book and looked at him.
“Usually, I don’t give my name to people whom I just met 10 minutes ago.” she got back to her book.
“Well, without a name I’m afraid I’ll have to resort to calling you missus for the next five minutes,” Jack sighed dejectedly slumping down into his chair.
Elsa’s attention shot back to him.
“Elsa.

It’s Elsa.”
Jack’s facade faded, cheering up over something as simple as a name.
“Elsa.
A name fit for the pretty missus,” he awed at her name.

“I’m Jackson by the way, but you can call me Jack.”
She nodded, acknowledging what he said, too bothered to respond.
“So… Elsa.” Jack sought to continue their conversation.
“Why a dictionary?
And why are you so into reading a dictionary,” he put emphasis on ‘dictionary’ twice.

Without putting the book down, she responded lightly, “because Jack, a dictionary is educational.”
Jack guffawed.
He couldn’t process why people would voluntarily read, much less read to learn.

Elsa sighed and elaborated, “don’t you find yourself lacking the right word to use sometimes?”
Jack shrugged, “Not really, not everything needs words to explain it with.”
“Plus, even if I did lack the right words, reading a dictionary is not worth it,” he had emphasized the word ‘dictionary’ three times now.
She glared at him, unamused.
At this point, she figured mockery is a habit of his and there’s no use in losing her demeanor over it— again.
“It’s also to keep nosy, white-haired baristas away,” she added smugly.
“Or, it can be a great conversation starter,” Jack added on to her claim with his own.

“And mine’s actually proven too.”
She rolled her eyes, “I’ve only read a dictionary in public once, it’s best not to draw conclusions yet.”
“Also, I think I look good in white hair.
It really makes my eyes pop.” Jack added as he remembered her comment about his hair color.

“Plus, your hair is not much darker than mine.”
“At least it’s natural,” she muttered, head returning to her book.
Jack laughed, eyeing her dictionary.
“I mean, words are cool and all but I like to express my thoughts through art,” he revived their dictionary topic, realizing his last comment unknowingly pulled her string— again.

He smirked, “In fact, this whole shop is filled with my art.”
Afraid to lose Elsa’s attention to the dictionary, settled in her hand, once more, Jack pointed out his latest ‘work of art.’ 
“See that?” he smiled proudly.

“That’s the newest piece to my collection.”
Elsa turned to the direction his finger was pointing.
“Eh… that looks… nice…?” she stared at it, wondering what— and why it was.
Jack couldn’t help but snicker at her speechlessness, surprised that her vocabulary still included basic words like ‘nice’ and words that aren’t even real words like ‘eh’.
She turned back to him, a sudden trace of curiosity crept its way on her face.
“I’ve been wondering, why is this place so discreet?
I didn’t even notice there was a window that faces the street.” Elsa questioned, motioning her head to the window on her right.
“Well, the window is tinted from the outside.
But from the inside, we can see everything out there clearly,” Jack answered, motioning his head to the other side of the window.
“But why?
Shouldn’t it be clear from the outside to, you know, attract customers?
Even in the rain, this place is… empty.” She looked around, confirming the latter.
“Well, first off, we’re financially stable thanks to our loyal customers,” Jack replied, beckoning to Sandy and Pitch.

“And even though we don’t make nearly as much as our neighbors, I’d have it no other way.”
Jack leaned back in his chair, one leg crossed over the other, and hands over his head, forming a makeshift pillow.
His lidded eyes completed the look.
“Besides, thanks to my artistic abilities, it’s like our own little world in here, away from one of the busiest cities in the world,” he continued, opening one of his eyes to look at Elsa.
Elsa looked around, cautiously taking in the sight of the small store surrounding her once more.
He was right.
Although it might look irregular at the first inspection, she realized that every odd trinket and their complementary place in the shop was intentional.

She couldn't help but draw similarities between the ‘flower-coffee shop’ and the taverns and greenhouses she envisioned so many times before, when submerged in a good fantasy book, full of wizards, knights, princes, and queens.
The place felt magical— even without the magic, much like a… Wonderland.
She smiled to herself.
It really was a different world from the one just over the window.
“You really thought it all out, didn’t you—?
The interior and design of this place I mean,” she asked Jack, admiration clearly painted on her face.
Jack blinked.
“Uh, no not really,” he confessed.

“I just went with my gut.”
“But if I had to lie to sway you, then yes, all of this took hours of thinking to come up with,” he smirked, fist lightly tapping his head.
She rolled her eyes.
“How did you even get the owner to let you put up all the…” she contemplated on the right word to finish her question with.

“Works of art?”
Jack laughed at her.
“I don’t need approval.

I’m the owner.”
Elsa’s eyes widened in surprise.
“You?

But you don’t look older than 18.”
“I’m offended,” Jack faked a sob.

“I’ll have you know I’m 21, I’m legal.”
She rolled her eyes— again at the last part.
“Okay, but aren’t you also a college student?’ she started.
“Most people opt to go to college nowadays,” she added, making sure he knows that her question was out of pure curiosity and had no rude intentions.
“Nope, after graduating high school, I chose to open this store with the help of my family and friends.” Jack smiled, recalling the support he’d received from those close to him.

“And I wouldn’t have it any other way.”
“What about you?
How old are you?
I’m assuming you’re still in school?” He directed the subject of conversation to her.

And yeah, a business major.” 
Jack smiled for the hundredth time that day, soreness creeping on his cheeks.

“Well that explains why you were wondering about the lack of customers and our profits.”
“I guess so.
It’s in our best interests,” she flushed slightly, embarrassed at her intruding question just a few minutes ago.
A comfortable silence befell the two as Elsa found her way back to the book in her hand, and as Jack turned his focus to the world on the other side of the window.
Priorly lost in each other’s company, they hadn’t noticed the rain outside had begun to pour down harder.
Jack looked outside and grimaced.

“It’s gonna be awhile till the rain stops.”
Elsa nodded glumly.

“I noticed you ordered an iced latté, does the cold weather not bother you?” Jack strived to continue their pleasant conversation from before, refusing to sit in silence with the girl, who, unbeknownst to herself, gained more and more of his affection.
“Nope, I like the cold.

Not the rain, but the cold.”
Jack eagerly looked at her, “I agree, the cold is awesome.

And a snow day would make it more awesome.”
“Yes, a snow-day would be nice!” Elsa excitedly replied, thinking back to the snow days she’d experienced and how she had all but positive memories of them.
Jack couldn’t help but soften at her newfound giddiness.

“I wouldn’t be surprised if you were the Snow Queen in your past life.”
“And I wouldn’t be surprised if you turned out to be the reincarnation of the Winter Spirit, Jack Frost,” she rebutted his joke with her own.
“I wouldn’t be surprised either.” Jack chuckled.

“But I bet he wouldn’t have been able to grow flowers, y’know, with his powers and all.”
His mention of flowers re-ignited Elsa’s curiosity, reminding her of an inquiry that slipped her mind.
“Say, why flower shop?

I mean it could’ve been anything else, so why a flower shop?”
At her question, Jack found himself pondering for the first time in a long while.

“So,” he started, his hand reaching into his pocket to retrieve something, fighting to resist a smile
He leaned over the table, towards Elsa.
“I can put another flower in your hair,” he teased, flashing his signature lopsided smirk as his hands work to carefully secure the flower in her platinum-blonde locks.

He retreated back to his seat, “Now, you look even more beautiful with two flowers in your hair!”
Jack’s cheeks were tinted red, but nowhere as near as Elsa’s hue of dangerously bright pink.
“W-Was that your way of f-flirting with me?” she squeaked incredulously, choking on her words.
Cute.
Jack thought.
“You know, Elsa, you ask quite a lot of questions,” Jack stood up, laughing.
“Considering you only had five minutes,” he winked.
At that remark, Elsa’s recovery was in vain because her face tinged a brighter shade.
She groaned, bringing her book up to shield her vulnerable face from the conniving barista, but at the same time, trying to hide her disappointment at his departure.
He may or he may not have noticed her crestfallen face, but as if on cue, he reached down to grab her empty cup.
“I’ll be back with your refill and my own iced drink,” he said between grins.
To his words, Elsa lightened up.
“Alright,” she responded passively, hiding her elation.

“I look forward to your return.”
“Keep talking like that and I won’t return,” Jack teased, poking fun at her professional manner of talking.
Hmph.
Elsa huffed and fake-pouted at his mockery.
“Be back in a jiffy,” he reassured her, walking back to the counter.
Elsa sat in quietness, left to savor Pitch’s tapping and Sandy’s tranquil humming.
She turned to the window.
The rain was no more.
And the once almost empty Manhattan streets were livened with a fresh set of scrambling commuters, eager to head home from their evening shift.
But despite the cloud’s parting and the comeback of the sun’s awaited rays, she allowed herself to continue sitting in her sequestered world, anticipating Jack’s return.
Smiling in content, she surrendered her book back to her bag, her hands ridded of the companion for the first time that afternoon.

Nights like these were his favorite: when the air was crisp and sharp—even for someone whose lungs didn’t work— when the temperature was cool enough for a blue hoodie and bare feet, when the sky was without a single cloud in sight—when the earth was laid bare and naked to the heavens above.
Nights like these remind him of Arendelle.
The Guardian of Fun smiled to himself as he drew the connection between Burgess and Arendelle.
Hell, did everything remind him of Arendelle?
Yes, yes they did.
Well for a good reason he supposed.
Actually, it’s hard to not compare—which was a bit unfair really as Arendelle would always reign above all.
He smirked as he reminds himself of the reason why.
He should probably get his responsibilities over with if he missed said kingdom this much.
If he missed her this much.
He wanted to see her again.

As the wind took him for a ride around Burgess, assisting him in his duty of bringing snow days to the unsuspecting people below, Jack Frost wondered to himself: Does she miss him the way he misses her?
He fucking hopes so—and maybe— just maybe, he would like to claim he knows so.
But as powerful as the Guardians of Childhood are, their magic is oh so limited.

So try as he might, he’ll never really know for sure what Elsa was thinking—and the closest he’ll ever get is when she wears her heart on her sleeves (which was rare in itself, especially as she got older).
But… with or without the power to know what she’s thinking, he thinks it was never safer to assume she did—that she had in fact missed him.
He might even dare say she loves him.
Jack’s heart smiled at the thought, somersaulting with joy inside his ribcage like him in the wind’s grasp.
But the logic that resides deep within him thought otherwise.
Please, you’re not even together that way.
Jack’s face soured.
Being optimistic was good and all, but, at least retain some form of reason.
And maybe then, the fall won’t hurt as much if it’s expected… if your hopes weren’t that high-achieving, to begin with.
Jack Frost bit the inside of his lip grimly.
Was that blood he tasted?
Who ever knows for sure?
And he wasn’t willing to find out.

~~~

Jack Frost wasn’t much of a thinker (and he was never really a doer either).
He went where the wind takes him.
Wherever the wind thought fit to bring him next, he obliged without a question.
But tonight, he felt the need to stray from the wind’s will, he wanted to confront someone about something—about the weird, ever-growing feeling in his non-beating heart.
So for the first time in a long while, Jack Frost pondered.
And he had used the whole fly to Arendelle to do it.
He’d known Elsa for well over 12 years now.
Since she was around 5 years old or so.
He knew just how much she’d been through— after all— he was right beside her for the whole of it, no?
Maybe that was why she still believed in him, why she could still see him.
He would be lying to himself—and to the rest of the world— if he said he didn’t fear the idea of her not ever being to see him again, of how, one day, she would walk right through the ghost of him.
But after many late-night talks and deep, life-questioning conversations, he came to believe—to hope— that that wouldn’t happen.
That, unlike Jamie, Elsa was different.
She wasn’t a special case.
She wasn’t… but she went ahead and became one.
And she had years over Jamie to prove it.
At first, it was just a friendship.
A very, real and raw friendship.
Between two people who are so alike yet so different in their many many unique ways—in ways, the rest of the world could only ever hope to understand.
But years later, when Elsa neared his age, he couldn’t help but wonder.
Elsa was beautiful.
She was never not so.
He knew it.
But it just took him a tad bit longer to realize that the new unknowing feeling in his frozen heart was love.
Attraction is a very weird thing indeed but hey, can you really blame him?
For being eternally 17?
No, no you cannot.
It wasn’t that way at first, and it wasn’t his fault Elsa was growing.

~~~

Jack’s flight was nearing an end as he can see the familiar silhouette of Arendelle castle in the far distance.
Like Burgess, the night was clear, rendering him bare to the stars above, to the moon, to Manny.
He growled to himself as his mind passed over the thought of Manny.
Does he know of Jack’s intentions to confess tonight?
Jack sure hopes not.
But it wouldn’t be a very Manny thing to not know.
(And why did the word ‘confess’ feel so weird?
Or was it the idea of it?
Maybe confrontation was the better term.)
As he neared his destination, his heart got all the more closer to his throat, clawing its way out.
Save me from the embarrassment.
It screams.
Jack couldn’t agree more.
Where was this heightened level of confidence coming from?
Had Sandy done something to mess with his subconscious again?
But he knew the answer deep down.
Asking useless questions was just a way of coping.
His selfish self wasn’t okay with the idea of what he already is to Elsa, he wanted to be something more, more than what he already is to her: a guardian and a (best) friend.

And unless the quick (un)secretive glances, the not pulling away from physical touch, the closer-than-personal-space-close interactions, and the shared looks of fondness were something just friends did, then his success rate tonight was high—if he does say so himself.
And then he was finally here.
He picked up his heart as he sighed for the last time that night before stepping into her window, open as it waits for him.
His mind runs over the rehearsal of his intended words once more.
Maybe if he willed it hard enough, his feelings would be reciprocated.
“I love you.
So please say you love me too.”
